TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}

S.FORM: izua sitsuayan marekałaałak a matjelu.
izoa sicoayan marekaljaaljak a matjelo.
S.TRANSL: Once upon a time there was a family of three.

S.FORM: uzai a ałak nua kina a lumamad anan.
ozai a aljak noa kina a lomamad anan.
S.TRANSL: The mother had a child which was still a baby,

S.FORM: qau sipasevał tua ałak a tjałavuluvulungan a vavayan.
qao sipasevalj toa aljak a tjaljavolovolongan a vavayan.
S.TRANSL: which she gave to the oldest girl to carry on her back.

S.FORM: qau sa vaik a kina a kivurasi.
qao sa vaik a kina a kivorasi.
S.TRANSL: And the mother went off to get sweet potatoes.

S.FORM: manu tsuay anga aravats, qemaung a keḍikeḍi.
mano coay anga aravac, qemaong a kedrikedri.
S.TRANSL: After a long time the baby cried.

S.FORM: qau katsuin nazua tjavulung a kaka pasa tjua kina.
qao kacoin nazoa tjavolong a kaka pasa tjoa kina.
S.TRANSL: So the older sister took him to their mother.

S.FORM: qau kiłavaran a ałak a tjałavuluvulungan: "sualapu ti aḍing a qemaung," ayain a kina.
qao kiljavaran a aljak a tjaljavolovolongan: "soalapo ti adring a qemaong," ayain a kina.
S.TRANSL: The oldest child said: “Take the boy away; he’s crying,” she said to her mother.

S.FORM: łakua "gału anan; kivurasi anan aken," aya kina.
ljakoa "galjo anan; kivorasi anan aken," aya kina.
S.TRANSL: But the mother said: “Wait a bit; I’m still getting sweet potatoes.”

S.FORM: qemaung aravats a keḍikeḍi.
qemaong aravac a kedrikedri.
S.TRANSL: The baby cried a lot.

S.FORM: "sualapu ti aḍing," ayain anan uta a kina.
"soalapo ti adring," ayain anan ota a kina.
S.TRANSL: “Take the boy away,” the girl said once more to her mother.

S.FORM: łakua ini sualapi angata.
ljakoa ini soalapi angata.
S.TRANSL: But she just would not take him.

S.FORM: qau keman tua tsengeł; ini pakani.
qao keman toa cengelj; ini pakani.
S.TRANSL: She ate lunch, but didn’t feed the children.

S.FORM: qau kisankuya azua kakeḍian; vaik a sema qapaz.
qao kisankoya azoa kakedrian; vaik a sema qapaz.
S.TRANSL: The children were angry, and went away to the edge of the field.

S.FORM: qau sa pedii a siała katua tjalikuvał tu sanpalałen niamadju a maḍusa.
qao sa pedii a sialja katoa tjalikovalj to sanpalaljen niamadjo a madrosa.
S.TRANSL: The carrying-cloth and the baby blanket were torn up to make wings for the two of them;

S.FORM: qau kitsaquan tiamadju a milayap.
qao kicaqoan tiamadjo a milayap.
S.TRANSL: and they practised flying.

S.FORM: qau tsuay anga aravats vaiken a karim nua kina.
qao coay anga aravac vaiken a karim noa kina.
S.TRANSL: After a long time the mother went to look for them.

S.FORM: mintu kitsaquaquan a milayap.
minto kicaqoaqoan a milayap.
S.TRANSL: And they were practising flying.

S.FORM: "aku maitazuazua mun?" ayain nua kina a kiłavaran a kakeḍian.
"ako maitazoazoa mon?" ayain noa kina a kiljavaran a kakedrian.
S.TRANSL: “Why are you doing that?” said the mother to the children.

S.FORM: "vaiku a tjumaq," ayain azua kakeḍian.
"vaiko a tjomaq," ayain azoa kakedrian.
S.TRANSL: “Go home!” the children were told.

S.FORM: łakua ini kisalu a vaik.
ljakoa ini kisalo a vaik.
S.TRANSL: But they wouldn’t go.

S.FORM: "muri masan qayaqayam amen," aya kiłavaran tua kina.
"mori masan qayaqayam amen," aya kiljavaran toa kina.
S.TRANSL: “We’re going to become birds,” they said to their mother.

S.FORM: qau kagarangan nua kina.
qao kagarangan noa kina.
S.TRANSL: The mother scolded them.

S.FORM: milayap a mavilad a sema tsemtsemel.
milayap a mavilad a sema cemcemel.
S.TRANSL: They flew off to the woods.

S.FORM: qau azua kakeḍian małavar tiamadju: "tisun layapu a maka kaledep; tiaken a maka maza i katsedas," ayain nua tjavulung a tjałałak.
qao azoa kakedrian maljavar tiamadjo: "tison layapo a maka kaledep; tiaken a maka maza i kacedas," ayain noa tjavolong a tjaljaljak.
S.TRANSL: The children discussed together: “You fly in the west; I’ll be here in the east,” said the older one to the younger one.

S.FORM: qau muri mavaday anga tiamadju; matjatjuktjuk.
qao mori mavaday anga tiamadjo; matjatjoktjok.
S.TRANSL: They were going to part, and they touched beaks.

S.FORM: qau sa kałavar: "nu metsevung itjen, uła quḍaquḍasan anga," aya tiamadju.
qao sa kaljavar: "no mecevong itjen, olja qodraqodrasan anga," aya tiamadjo.
S.TRANSL: And they said to one another: “Let’s be white-haired when we meet again,” they said.

S.FORM: qau milayap anga tiamadju a mavadai a maḍusa.
qao milayap anga tiamadjo a mavadai a madrosa.
S.TRANSL: And the two of them flew off and parted.

S.FORM: qau metsevung tiamadju ka quḍaquḍasan anga tiamadju a qayaqayam.
qao mecevong tiamadjo ka qodraqodrasan anga tiamadjo a qayaqayam.
S.TRANSL: They met again when they were white-haired birds.

S.FORM: qau małavar anan tiamadju uta: "tisun ngangay aya-u anga.
qao maljavar anan tiamadjo ota: "tison ngangay aya-o anga.
S.TRANSL: And they talked to one another again: “You say ‘ngangay’,

S.FORM: tiaken tjugelui ayanga aken nu zemaing," ayain a tjałałak.
tiaken tjogeloi ayanga aken no zemaing," ayain a tjaljaljak.
S.TRANSL: and I’ll say ‘tjugelui’ when we call,” the younger one was told.

S.FORM: avan sika uzai anga nua tjugelui katua ngangay tutsu.
avan sika ozai anga noa tjogeloi katoa ngangay toco.
S.TRANSL: And that’s why there are the ngangay (white owl) and tjugelui (brown owl) to this day.
